arm_group.description: Endothelial function, oxidative stress and inflammation were measured before and after CMR.

The subjects keep supine position the MR machine as same time as experimental group when the MR machine is power off. The endothelial function, oxidative stress and inflammation were measured before and after this procedure".  This group is called the non-CMR group or sham CMR group.
Healthy subjects (30) will be enrolled as controls at baseline.

brief_summary.textblock:
Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging is a widely used and well-established noninvasive medical
      diagnostic imaging tool. By using a static and a gradient magnetic field in combination with
      a radiofrequency field (RF), MR provides excellent contrast among different tissues of the
      body. Although long-term effects on human health from exposure to strong static magnetic
      fields seem unlikely, acute effects such as vertigo, nausea, change in blood pressure,
      reversible arrhythmia, and neurobehavioural effects have been documented from occupational
      exposition to 1.5 T. Cardiac MR (CMR) imaging requires some of the strongest and fastest
      switching electromagnetic gradients available in MR exposing the patients to the highest
      administered energy levels accepted by the controlling authorities. Studies focusing on
      experimental teratogenic or carcinogenic effects of MR revealed conflicting results. Since
      CMR is emerging as one of the fastest growing new fields of broad MR application, it is of
      particular concern that a recent in vitro study with CMR sequences has reported on
      CMR-induced DNA damages in white blood cells up to 24 h after exposure to 1.5 T CMR.
      Therefore, we hypothesized that CMR can induce the damage of endothelium and endothelial
      progenitor cells in type 2 diabetes

clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of Cardiac Magnetic Resonance Imaging on Endothelial Function in Type 2 Diabetes

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Male

          -  Age 30 to 65 years old

          -  Type 2 diabetes

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Renal and liver function dysfunction

          -  Heart failure

          -  Malignancy

          -  Patients with contraindications to cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR)

          -  Patients with clinical detectable angiopathy

clinical_study.official_title: Impact of Cardiac Magnetic Resonance Imaging on Endothelial Function in Type 2 Diabetes

primary_outcome.description: The endothelium-dependent arterial dilation was measured at baseline, 1day, 2 day, 3 day after CMR.
primary_outcome.measure: Changes of endothelium-dependent arterial dilation before and after CMR in type 2 diabetes

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Wuhan General Hospital of Guangzhou Military Command
responsible_party.investigator_title: Director of Endocrinology, Wuhan General Hospital

secondary_outcome.description: The numbers of endothelial progenitor cells was determined at baseline, 1 day, 2 day, 3 day after CMR.
secondary_outcome.measure: Changes of endothelial progenitor cells before and after CMR in peripheral blood

clinical_study.source: Wuhan General Hospital of Guangzhou Military Command
clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Health Services Research
